poem:
**Pattern Recognition**

In fields of willow, blackthorn whispers,  
Morris blooms where teal and ochre twine.  
Submarines thread seas with floral whispers,  
A craftsman's hand, both ageless and benign.  
On curtains drawn and tables set,  
Fast-fashion finds its quiet muse—  
In patterns past, present chooses,  
In pimpernel print, what dreams we use.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Curtains, wellies, nuclear subs and a tsar’s palace: how William Morris mania swept the world He has papered our walls and carpeted our floors, enlivened our curtains, coats and cups, and even infiltrated Britain’s nuclear submarine fleet. Almost 130 years after his death, the Victorian arts and crafts designer William Morris has blanketed the world with his unmistakable brand of busy floral patterns, wrapping our lives with tasteful swathes of willow, blackthorn and pimpernel, peppered". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
